items.title: zmq.error.ZMQError: Address in use (after reboot)
items.body:
I am running a virtualenv on windows 10 
python 3.7.4
anaconda 1.9.2

I am running the command:
python -m spyder_kernels.console

and I am getting the output:

```
Exception in thread Thread-4:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "E:\Anaconda3\lib\threading.py", line 926, in _bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "E:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\ipykernel\heartbeat.py", line 91, in run
    self._bind_socket()
  File "E:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\ipykernel\heartbeat.py", line 74, in _bind_socket
    self._try_bind_socket()
  File "E:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\ipykernel\heartbeat.py", line 61, in _try_bind_socket
    return self.socket.bind('%s://%s' % (self.transport, self.ip) + c + str(self.port))
  File "zmq/backend/cython/socket.pyx", line 550, in zmq.backend.cython.socket.Socket.bind
  File "zmq/backend/cython/checkrc.pxd", line 25, in zmq.backend.cython.checkrc._check_rc
zmq.error.ZMQError: Address in use
To connect another client to this kernel, use:

    --existing kernel-8296.json
```

I tried rebooting the computer and it is still happening. 
What can I do to get rid of this? It was working before,

items.title: Maximum recursion depth exceeded
items.body:
## Description

### What steps will reproduce the problem?

<!--- You can use Markdown here --->

I was only invoking a user-defined function written in another Python module.

### Traceback
```python-traceback
Exception in comms call get_namespace_view:
  File "C:\Users\sanja\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\spyder_kernels\comms\commbase.py", line 342, in _handle_remote_call
    buffer['call_kwargs'])
  File "C:\Users\sanja\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\spyder_kernels\comms\commbase.py", line 353, in _remote_callback
    *call_args, **call_kwargs)
  File "C:\Users\sanja\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\spyder_kernels\console\kernel.py", line 182, in get_namespace_view
    view = make_remote_view(ns, settings, EXCLUDED_NAMES)
  File "C:\Users\sanja\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\spyder_kernels\utils\nsview.py", line 703, in make_remote_view
    'size':  get_size(value),
  File "C:\Users\sanja\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\spyder_kernels\utils\nsview.py", line 126, in get_size
    return item.shape
  File "C:\Users\sanja\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\base.py", line 633, in shape
    return self._values.shape
  File "C:\Users\sanja\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\generic.py", line 5272, in __getattr__
    if self._info_axis._can_hold_identifiers_and_holds_name(name):
  File "C:\Users\sanja\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\generic.py", line 5272, in __getattr__
    if self._info_axis._can_hold_identifiers_and_holds_name(name):
  File "C:\Users\sanja\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\generic.py", line 5272, in __getattr__
    if self._info_axis._can_hold_identifiers_and_holds_name(name):
  [Previous line repeated 1485 more times]
  File "C:\Users\sanja\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\generic.py", line 493, in _info_axis
    return getattr(self, self._info_axis_name)
  File "C:\Users\sanja\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\generic.py", line 5270, in __getattr__
    return object.__getattribute__(self, name)
  File "pandas\_libs\properties.pyx", line 63, in pandas._libs.properties.AxisProperty.__get__

    return object.__getattribute__(self, name)
RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object
```

items.title: double declaration of ipykernel causes poetry to fail
items.body:
I tried to manage project using poetry
https://python-poetry.org
double declaration of `ipykernel` causes poetry to fail https://github.com/python-poetry/poetry/issues/2133

```
REQUIREMENTS = [
  ...
    'ipykernel',
    'ipykernel>=5.1.3; python_version>"2"',
  ...
]
```

After removing one of the dependcies ` poetry` could  install all packages.

items.title: saved session data scrambled(Save data as)
items.body:
* [x] Searched 
* [x] Read
* [x] Reproduced the issue
* [ ] Could not reproduce 
* [ x] Tried basic troubleshooting 
* [x] Completed the **Problem Description**, **Steps to Reproduce** and **Version** sections below


## Problem Description
"save data as" in the variable explorer scrambled all the lists in my SPYDERDATA file. I have lists of array that are my data and indices of events related to those data (EEG experiment). I can see they are scrambled from the length of the arrays (array 3 in list A should have the same length of array 3 in lists B and C , which is not the case)..

The first one or two arrays of each list  (of 3200 arrays) seem to be in the right place

Every time i reopen the file i get different lists of the same arrays, in other words the order of the arrays is changed.

Is there any way to recover the original structure of my data?

Thank you in advance. 


## Versions

* Spyder version: 3.3.1
* Python version: 3.5.2 64
* Qt version: 5.6.2

items.title: unable to launch kernel V1.8.1
items.body:
I did `conda install spyder-kernels` and got V1.8.1 on my fresh Linux aarch64 box

```
(base) anonymous@romeo:~$ conda list | grep spyder-kernels
spyder-kernels            1.8.1                    py37_0
(base) anonymous@romeo:~$
```
but starting the kernel now with `python -m spyder_kernels.console` yields :
```
(base) anonymous@romeo:~$ python spyder-kernels.console
python: can't open file 'spyder-kernels.console': [Errno 2] No such file or directory
(base) anonymous@romeo:~$
```
On windows the same thing happens (also got spyder-kernels V1.8.1 there):
```
(base) C:\Users\hoeren>python spyder-kernels.console
python: can't open file 'spyder-kernels.console': [Errno 2] No such file or directory
(base) C:\Users\hoeren>
```
Ok, so I execute the procedure in [`spyder_kernels/console/__main__.py`](https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder-kernels/blob/master/spyder_kernels/console/__main__.py) by hand in the console, and than I get a `MultipleInstanceError`, so somewhere this exception is caught and (carelessly) re-raised as `[Errno 2] No such file or directory`
```
(base) anonymous@romeo:~$ ipython
Python 3.7.6 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Jan  7 2020, 21:51:31)
Type 'copyright', 'credits' or 'license' for more information
IPython 7.11.1 -- An enhanced Interactive Python. Type '?' for help.

In [1]: from spyder_kernels.console import start

In [2]: start.main()
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
MultipleInstanceError                     Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-4cf62eeb54be> in <module>
----> 1 start.main()

~/miniforge3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/spyder_kernels/console/start.py in main()
    298     from spyder_kernels.console.kernel import SpyderKernel
    299
--> 300     kernel = IPKernelApp.instance()
    301     kernel.kernel_class = SpyderKernel
    302     try:

~/miniforge3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/site-packages/traitlets/config/configurable.py in instance(cls, *args, **kwargs)
    421             raise MultipleInstanceError(
    422                 'Multiple incompatible subclass instances of '
--> 423                 '%s are being created.' % cls.__name__
    424             )
    425

MultipleInstanceError: Multiple incompatible subclass instances of IPKernelApp are being created.

In [3]: 
```
anyway, things go wrong in `IPKernelApp`, and that is provided by `ipykernel` ... and that is `V1.5.4` on my box. So `V1.5.4` is thus **not** just `V1.5.3` with **only** added aarch64 support ... some other things (API changes ?!?) did slip in with the recent release of `V1.5.4` 😭 

So, whatever you do, **please** keep the pinning `ipykernel >=5.1.3` in [conda-forge/spyder-kernels-feedstock/blob/master/recipe/meta.yaml](https://github.com/conda-forge/spyder-kernels-feedstock/blob/master/recipe/meta.yaml) as when you change it to `ipykernel =5.1.3` I again lose the ability to run `spyder-kernels` on aarch64 😡

items.title: Weakrefs fail to finalize
items.body:
<!--- **PLEASE READ:** When submitting here, please ensure you've completed the following checklist and checked the boxes to confirm. Issue reports without it may be closed. Thanks! --->

### Issue Report Checklist

* [x] Searched the [issues page](https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder/issues?q=is%3Aissue) for similar reports
* [x] Read the relevant sections of the [Spyder Troubleshooting Guide](https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder/wiki/Troubleshooting-Guide-and-FAQ) and followed its advice
* [x] Reproduced the issue after updating with ``conda update spyder`` (or ``pip``, if not using Anaconda)
* [x] Could not reproduce inside ``jupyter qtconsole`` (if console-related)
* [x] Tried basic troubleshooting (if a bug/error)
    * [x] Restarted Spyder
    * [x] Reset preferences with ``spyder --reset``
    * [x] Reinstalled the latest version of [Anaconda](https://www.anaconda.com/download/)
    * [x] Tried the other applicable steps from the Troubleshooting Guide
* [x] Completed the **Problem Description**, **Steps to Reproduce** and **Version** sections below


## Problem Description

Weakrefs fail to finalize in Spyder >= 4.0.0.

### What steps reproduce the problem?

1. Run file:
```python
import tempfile
import time
import os
import weakref
class FileTest:
    def __init__(self):
        self.t = tempfile.mkstemp(prefix="Spyder_weakref_test")
        weakref.finalize(self, self.close)
    def close(self):
        os.close(self.t[0])
        os.remove(self.t[1])
if __name__ == "__main__":
    test = FileTest()
    time.sleep(1)
```
2. Close the current kernel (or shutdown spyder)
3. Observe that the tempfile was not deleted (it is deleted in older spyder)

Note (edit: I never finished this thought earlier): On many of the commits while bisecting, I applied the following small patch to make sure that the kernel started up at all (Still had some unrelated errors, but got it working enough to look for what I was testing). My needing to apply the patch was introduced in the same commit, and it was _not_ necessary on current `spyder` master. Without it I was getting `AttributeError: 'NamespaceBrowser' object has no attribute 'show_callable_attributes'` and the kernel never actually started.

```diff
diff --git a/spyder/widgets/variableexplorer/namespacebrowser.py b/spyder/widgets/variableexplorer/namespacebrowser.py
index da534d3c9..b19785e01 100644
--- a/spyder/widgets/variableexplorer/namespacebrowser.py
+++ b/spyder/widgets/variableexplorer/namespacebrowser.py
@@ -236,7 +236,8 @@ class NamespaceBrowser(QWidget):
         """Return dict editor view settings"""
         settings = {}
         for name in REMOTE_SETTINGS:
-            settings[name] = getattr(self, name)
+            if hasattr(self, name):
+                settings[name] = getattr(self, name)
         return settings

     def refresh_table(self):
```

### What is the expected output? What do you see instead?

It is expected that the temporary file will be deleted upon closing of the kernel

## Versions
<!--- You can get this information from Help > About Spyder...
or (if Spyder won't launch) the "conda list" command
from the Anaconda Prompt/Terminal/command line. --->

* Spyder version: 
   - Bisected to 2c917bff3a4490c9d8db7ba8c911f17adef7e3ed (This was where spyder-kernels>=1.0 became required, could be related)
   - Verified bug on current conda-forge release release (4.0.1)
   - Observed on current git master (a05d71399d17e48b4b5ff9a2aca2b2795afbba70)
* Python version: 3.7, 3.8
* Qt version: 5.9.3
* PyQt version: 5.9.2
* Operating System name/version: Debian Linux (sid/unstable), Ubuntu Mate 16.04, Windows 10

### Dependencies
<!--- Please go to the menu entry Help > Dependencies,
press the Copy to clipboard button and paste below --->
(Note this is from the end of bisecting on 2c917bff3a4490c9d8db7ba8c911f17adef7e3ed, done in a fresh venv at the start of bisecting)
```
pyflakes >=0.6.0  :  2.1.1 (OK)
pycodestyle >=2.3 :  2.5.0 (OK)
pygments >=2.0    :  2.5.2 (OK)
sphinx >=0.6.6    :  2.3.1 (OK)
rope >=0.9.4      :  0.16.0 (OK)
jedi >=0.11.0     :  0.15.2 (OK)
psutil >=0.3      :  5.6.7 (OK)
nbconvert >=4.0   :  5.6.1 (OK)
pandas >=0.13.1   :  None (NOK)
numpy >=1.7       :  None (NOK)
sympy >=0.7.3     :  None (NOK)
cython >=0.21     :  None (NOK)
qtconsole >=4.2.0 :  4.6.0 (OK)
IPython >=4.0     :  7.11.1 (OK)
matplotlib >=2.0.0:  None (NOK)
pylint >=0.25     :  2.4.4 (OK)
```

items.title: error opening pandas DataFrame from variable explorer
items.body:
<!--- **PLEASE READ:** When submitting here, please ensure you've completed the following checklist and checked the boxes to confirm. Issue reports without it may be closed. Thanks! --->

### Issue Report Checklist

* [x] Searched the [issues page](https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder/issues?q=is%3Aissue) for similar reports
* [x] Read the relevant sections of the [Spyder Troubleshooting Guide](https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder/wiki/Troubleshooting-Guide-and-FAQ) and followed its advice
* [x] Reproduced the issue after updating with ``conda update spyder`` (or ``pip``, if not using Anaconda)
* [ ] Could not reproduce inside ``jupyter qtconsole`` (if console-related)
* [x] Tried basic troubleshooting (if a bug/error)
    * [x] Restarted Spyder
    * [x] Reset preferences with ``spyder --reset``
    * [x] Reinstalled the latest version of [Anaconda](https://www.anaconda.com/download/)
    * [x] Tried the other applicable steps from the Troubleshooting Guide
* [x] Completed the **Problem Description**, **Steps to Reproduce** and **Version** sections below


## Problem Description

If I use a different conda environment than the one spyder is installed in, I cannot open pandas dataframes.

Creating a pandas dataframe, either empty, manually or by importing with for example pandas.read_csv; in all cases if I try to open it in variable explorer I get the error message:

> error 'tuple' object has no attribute 'raise_error'

If i install pandas in the same environment where spyder is installed, it works fine.

I suspect it's because spyder doesn't use the dependency properly from the alternate environment? Because in the dependency list it looks like pandas is missing. But this of course goes away when I install pandas in the spyder environment.

### What steps reproduce the problem?

1. create a new conda environment, let's call it spyder (conda create -n spyder)
2. install spyder in this new spyder environment (conda install spyder=4.0.1)
3. create another conda environment, let's call it pandas_env (conda create -n pandas_env)
4. install pandas and spyder-kernels in the pandas_env environment (conda install pandas spyder-kernels)
5. start spyder from its environment
6. select "pandas_env" environment as the python interpreter (preferences -> python interpreter)
7. open new console so it uses newly selected environment
8. import pandas as pd 
9. bla = pd.DataFrame()
10. try to open bla in variable explorer, it will give error as stated above.
11. error remains after restarting spyder

(in one case after restarting spyder in step 11, the error popup was delayed so i double clicked many times on the variable which later caused spyder to crash with segmentation fault...)

### What is the expected output? What do you see instead?

I expect to be able to open and see the pandas dataframe but instead I see an error as per above.

## Versions
<!--- You can get this information from Help > About Spyder...
or (if Spyder won't launch) the "conda list" command
from the Anaconda Prompt/Terminal/command line. --->

* Spyder version: 4.0.1
* Python version: 3.7.6 (both envs)
* Qt version: 5.9.7 (spyder env)
* PyQt version: 5.9.2 (spyder env)
* Operating System name/version: macos 10.14.6
* conda version: 4.8.1
* spyder-kernels: 1.8.1 (in both envs)

### Dependencies
<!--- Please go to the menu entry Help > Dependencies,
press the Copy to clipboard button and paste below --->

```
applaunchservices >=0.1.7    :  0.2.1 (OK)
atomicwrites >=1.2.0         :  1.3.0 (OK)
chardet >=2.0.0              :  3.0.4 (OK)
```

items.title: Changing Environment's that have DLL references
items.body:
Referencing this page:https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder/wiki/Working-with-packages-and-environments-in-Spyder

There are steps for changing the conda environment, without installing a brand new instance of Spyder inside that environment. You can just point to the new environment's executable and restart the console.

The problem I'm running into, is that this doesn't work for modules that reference .DLLs or other external libraries. The reason is that os.environ["PATH"] remains unchanged, and only references the environment that Spyder is installed in(changing the .exe only changes sys.path).

Thus, the only way to work with these libraries inside Spyder is to activate the environment inside the console, launch Spyder from the console, and then follow the steps in the above link. This is hardly an elegant way, and I'm sure there is a better one. 

Running: `conda activate myenv ` inside the Ipython console and restarting the kernel does not solve it.

And if not, how can I explicitly activate the correct environment when launching Spyder from a shortcut or a shell script instead of Anaconda Prompt?

* Spyder version: 4.0
* Python version:  3.7.5
* Operating System name/version: Windows 10 x64

items.title: spydercustomize.runfile seems to be wrong version
items.body:
Just installed Spyder 4.
## Versions

* Spyder version: 4.0.0rc2 
* Python version: 3.7.0
* Qt version: 5.9.6
* PyQt5 version: 5.9.2
* Operating System: Darwin 19.0.0

When I run a script, I get this error:

```
Python 3.7.5 (default, Oct 25 2019, 10:52:18)
Type "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

IPython 7.9.0 -- An enhanced Interactive Python.

runfile('/Users/colinww/system-model/work/fft_block_lms_noise_analysis.py', wdir='/Users/colinww/system-model/work', current_namespace=True)
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "<ipython-input-1-73b5de20005a>", line 1, in <module>
    runfile('/Users/colinww/system-model/work/fft_block_lms_noise_analysis.py', wdir='/Users/colinww/system-model/work', current_namespace=True)

TypeError: runfile() got an unexpected keyword argument 'current_namespace'
```

Looking in the file `/Users/colinww/anaconda3/pkgs/spyder-kernels-1.8.0-py37_0/lib/python3.7/site-packages/spyder_kernels/customize/spydercustomize.py` shows the following:
```
def runfile(filename=None, args=None, wdir=None, namespace=None,
            post_mortem=False, current_namespace=False):
```
But,
```
runfile
Out[11]: <function spydercustomize.runfile(filename, args=None, wdir=None, namespace=None, post_mortem=False)>
```
So I'm trying to figure out from where Spyder is pulling this function definition (or what's wrong with my env to result in this behavior). I configured my spyder environment like this:
```
$ conda create --channel spyder-ide --name spyder-beta spyder=4.0.0rc2
$ conda activate spyder-beta
$ spyder
```
Thank you.

items.title: Regression: runfile doesn't execute ipython magic
items.body:
`ipython_shell.run_cell` was replaced by a straight call to `exec` in runcell, which means that the ipython magic are not executed anymore. The main raison for this change is that calling `exec` allows to correctly set the filename which:

 1. Allows Pdb to correctly set breakpoints. Otherwise it has no way of knowing the file the cell is in.
 2. Creates correct tracebacks when an exception is raised.

To restore this behaviour, `ipython_shell.run_cell` needs to be modified upstream. More specifically, `async def run_cell_async` needs to have an extra `file_name` argument to replace `cell_name`. The question that remain is: Do we want to support calling magic in `runfile` as well? This can be done by loading the file (`with open(...) as f:`) and using its content as a single cell. I don't think runfile and runcell should behave differently.

items.title: tests use removed pandas.Panel
items.body:
Pandas 0.25 has removed Panels: https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/whatsnew/v0.25.0.html
> Warning: Panel has been fully removed. For N-D labeled data structures, please use xarray 

It is used here:
https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder-kernels/blob/f281e8ead6c1d1414ad4050dd78a112a3b45fb96/spyder_kernels/utils/tests/test_nsview.py#L38


Pandas 0.25.0 has been released on July 18th.

items.title: Add test requirements to setup.py
items.body:
Please follow [the way](https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder/blob/master/setup.py#L241-L255) Spyder defines its test requirements through `extras_require` to declare our tests dependencies in the `setup.py` file placed here.

Since in `spyder_kernels` we are using setuptools directly, simply declare a constant called `TEST_REQUIREMENTS`, add the list of test packages to it and finally pass that to `extras_require` like this:

```python
setup(
    name='spyder-kernels',
    version=get_version(),
    ...
    install_requires=REQUIREMENTS,
    extras_require={'test': TEST_REQUIREMENTS}
    ...
)
```

Thanks!

items.title: Backport CI configuration from master to 0.x
items.body: @steff456, please reorganize our CI configuration for Travis, Appveyor and Circle as it's done in master. In other words, please remove our usage of `ci-helpers`, and use instead the files I put in the `requirements` directory and the scripts I placed in the `ci` directory.

items.title: Set matplotlib backend to inline by default on starting a new kernel
items.body:
Opened by request of @ccordoba12 

``spyder-kernels`` should set the graphics backend to ``inline`` by default on starting a ``spyder-kernels`` kernel, to match the Spyder default and so plots work by default on remote machines over ``ssh``. Currently, in my testing, plots in such consoles appear in interactive mode (i.e. Qt backend), rather than inline.

items.title: test_output_from_c_libraries fails on openSUSE Tumbleweed
items.body:
During packaging I have the test `test_output_from_c_libraries` failing:

```
________________________________________________________________ test_output_from_c_libraries ________________________________________________________________

kernel = <spyder_kernels.console.kernel.SpyderKernel object at 0x7effe0308128>, capsys = <_pytest.capture.CaptureFixture object at 0x7effe03086a0>

    @pytest.mark.skipif(os.name == 'nt', reason="Doesn't work on Windows")
    def test_output_from_c_libraries(kernel, capsys):
        """Test that the wurlitzer extension is working."""
        # This code was taken from the Wurlitzer demo
        code = """
    import ctypes
    libc = ctypes.CDLL(None)
    libc.printf(('Hello from C\\n').encode('utf8'))
    """
    
        # Without Wurlitzer there's not output generated
        # by the kernel
        reply = kernel.do_execute(code, True)
        captured = capsys.readouterr()
        assert captured.out == ''
    
        # With Wurlitzer we have the expected output
        kernel._load_wurlitzer()
        reply = kernel.do_execute(code, True)
        captured = capsys.readouterr()
>       assert captured.out == "Hello from C\n"
E       AssertionError: assert '' == 'Hello from C\n'
E         + Hello from C

spyder_kernels/console/tests/test_console_kernel.py:307: AssertionError
```

Do you know how I can solve that?

items.title: Tkinter is now required for version 0.4.3 after patching the turtle code
items.body:
With the merge of PR #90, Python now needs "to be configured for Tk" due to the explicit import of ```turtle``` (which in turn does ``` import Tkinter as TK```). I was updating ```py-spyder``` to version 3.3.4 in MacPorts and because of this I would need to add a dependency on ```py-tkinter```, which recursively pulls in ```tk```, ```tcl``` and their dependencies. We didn't do that before and whereas (admittedly) the same error would appear if someone selected the ```Tkinter``` backend, everything would work fine for the (default) "inline" or the "Qt5" backends.

I couldn't find the need of "having Python configured for Tk" in the requirements for spyder or spyder-kernels, did I miss this somewhere? I also suppose that the patching of the ```turtle``` code would only be relevant when choosing the Tkinter graphical backend and not for others - correct? If so, would it be possible to only do this when selecting the Tkinter backend? 

I'd appreciate your comments/suggestions and would welcome any advice you can give (regarding dependencies / backends) for downstream packagers.

items.title: Can't repeat runcell from terminal
items.body:
When calling runfile, I can just repeat the call in the terminal by pressing up + enter.
I use to be able to do that when running a cell as well. But since the introduction of the runcell function, I get:
```
--Run Cell Error--
Please use only through Spyder's Editor; shouldn't be called manually from the console
```
Maybe it would make sense to give the line number to runcell so it could be called from the terminal?

items.title: Detect the name of the file currently running the cell
items.body:
I think it would be useful to obtain the name of the file currently running the cell.

__spyder_cell_file__

It would be nice if I could get to the point in my script, that would programmatically:
 * Save the current working file
 * Copy it to some known directory for archival purposes

Checking for the existance of the `__file__` is a little problematic, because it can be set by a `run` command, and it won't be unset.

The current working directory if often clobbered when restarting kernels and navigating through the file explorer.

XREF: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54221512/get-name-of-file-where-the-cell-is-running-from-in-spyder/54224444#54224444

items.title: Namespace serialization silently fails if any object is unserializable, e.g. a Python module
items.body:
A user reported on Gitter that Spyder's namespace saving feature was silently failing in certain situations, and upon testing it, an easily reproducible was was attempting to serialize Python modules, which cannot be serialized and are rarely if ever desired to be in this case. To fix this, we should:

* Fix error messages not being printed by handling exceptions in the ``deepcopy()`` call properly
* Call deepcopy on each individual value rather than the whole dict/namespace, to prevent falling back to normal ``copy`` or nothing at all for everything if one object cannot be deepcopied (or serialized entirely)
* Skip serializing anything that is a Python module EDIT: Or a function/class, as they can only be loaded if they already exist in the environment (thus it serves little purpose to do so, other than the prevent the rest of the environment from being loaded)
* If an object produces an error on attempted serialization, skip it and generate a popup warning listing the objects not serialized rather than refusing to save the entire session and forcing users to manually figure out and delete problem ones

@ccordoba12 These changes fix a major bug in namespace serialization, can all be implemented purely in Spyder-Kernels without any Spyder-side changes; and all in a file that has no changes (and thus no chance of merge conflicts) between ``0.x`` and ``master``, so can this go in ``0.x``?

items.title: Error when opening variable in Variable explorer
items.body:
## Description

### What steps will reproduce the problem?

<!--- You can use Markdown here --->


```
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

data = np.genfromtxt('/home/somefile.csv',
                     names=True, delimiter=',')

test = data[1]                  
```
Now double click on "test" in the Variable explorer (nothing happens) and then click a third time. Now the "Issue reporter" opens up.

### Traceback

items.body: Find a replacement for `get_ipython`

items.title: Add tests for the console kernel
Startup lines to split with semicolon instead of comma
items.body:
## Issue
Currently I can't use a IPyhton startup lines like these in Sypder since the line is parsed with comma separation:

```python
from modual import func1, func2
```
or 
```python
import os, sys
```

These common python import structures don't work in startup lines. I actually thought it was broken until I read the note in the ipython config and thought about the implications of using comma separation.

## Solution

If we use semicolon to separate the lines like you can do in python then any valid python should be possible.

Then you could use:
```python
import os, sys; from modal import func1, func2
```

The fix could be as simple as changing this comma to a semicolon in this code, or the line could be executed directly since it is valid python.
 
https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder-kernels/blob/9a49376ec01ad41af5d3522758e5b4bb30ce85a8/spyder_kernels/console/start.py#L102-L106

## Potential Problem

This is a compatibility concern since the startup lines from 3 would not work in 4, but it's a good time to make a braking change or we can tell that a config file is from 3 it can be upgraded to 4 by replacing the commas with semicolons automatically.

items.title: Spydata files won't import if the original filename is changed
items.body:
@TinyCloud commented on [Tue Jul 17 2018](https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder/issues/7483)

<!--- **PLEASE READ:** Before submitting here, please carefully consult our *Troubleshooting Guide*: https://github.com/spyder-ide/spyder/wiki/Troubleshooting-Guide-and-FAQ and search the issues page for your error/problem, as most posted bugs are duplicates or easy fixes.

If you don't find anything, please provide a detailed step-by-step description (in English) of the problem and what led up to it below. Issue reports without a clear way to reproduce them will be closed. Thanks! --->

## Problem Description
Whenever I've saved a session's data as a .spydata file and tried to import it at a later point in time, the behavior is highly erratic - works sometimes and does not do anything sometimes.

### What steps will reproduce the problem?
- Export a copy of the session dataframes and variables by Save as from Variable explorer . Ex: test.spydata in your working directory.
- Use import from variable explorer to open the same file. Does not always work.


## Package Versions

* Spyder version: 3.2.8 
* Python version: 2.7.15
* Qt version: 5.9.4
* PyQt5 version: 5.9.2
* Operating system: Darwin 17.6.0

### Dependencies

```
pyflakes >=0.5.0  :  1.6.0 (OK)

pygments >=2.0    :  2.2.0 (OK)

```
